description:
Zophobas morio, commonly known as the Morio worm or superworm, is a species of darkling beetle larva. It belongs to the family Tenebrionidae, which is a large family of beetles found worldwide.

The Zophobas morio larva is a cylindrical, soft-bodied insect that can grow up to 5-6 centimeters in length. It has a brown or yellowish-brown coloration and a hard, chitinous exoskeleton. The larva has a distinct head with strong mandibles, which it uses to feed on a variety of organic materials, including decaying plant matter, fungi, and even other insects.

Zophobas morio larvae are known for their ability to withstand harsh environmental conditions, including high temperatures and low moisture levels. This makes them a popular choice as a feeder insect for various reptiles, amphibians, and birds kept as pets.

The life cycle of Zophobas morio involves an egg, larval, pupal, and adult stage. The larval stage is the longest and can last several months, depending on environmental conditions and food availability. When the larva is ready to pupate, it constructs a cocoon-like structure, where it undergoes metamorphosis and emerges as an adult darkling beetle.

Overall, Zophobas morio is a fascinating and resilient insect species that plays an important role in the decomposition of organic matter in its natural habitats.
